title: 104_hr892
content: The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 599 of title 28, United States Code, and provides a basis for preliminary investigation. The "Independent Counsel Accountability and Reform Act of 1995" amends Section 591 of title 28, United States Code, specifying that specific information from a credible source must be received within 15 days for the Attorney General to determine the need for a preliminary investigation. The Attorney General must close the matter if there is insufficient evidence of a violation of Federal criminal law within 15 days. If there is enough evidence, a preliminary investigation will be initiated. If unable to determine, a preliminary investigation will still commence after the 15-day period. Section 592(c)(2) of title 28, United States Code, requires specific information from a credible source for the Attorney General to act. SEC. 4. PROSECUTORIAL JURISDICTION OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. The prosecutorial jurisdiction of independent counsel is defined with specificity and limited to alleged violations of criminal law requested by the Attorney General. The independent counsel is granted authority to fully investigate and prosecute these violations and related matters. The independent counsel's jurisdiction is limited to alleged violations of criminal law requested by the Attorney General, including perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and intimidation of witnesses. The amendment clarifies that the counsel can investigate and prosecute these violations and related matters. The independent counsel is granted authorities and duties related to investigating and prosecuting alleged violations of criminal law, including perjury, obstruction of justice, destruction of evidence, and intimidation of witnesses. The independent counsel is provided with office space within a Federal building by the Administrator of General Services. Amendments are made to ensure compliance with Department of Justice policies, including the enforcement of criminal laws and the release of information. There is a limitation on expenditures for the independent counsel. The Independent Counsel Reauthorization Act of 1994 repeals certain provisions and imposes limitations on expenditures for the operation of any office of independent counsel after a 2-year period. SEC. 6. REMOVAL, TERMINATION, AND PERIODIC REAPPOINTMENT OF INDEPENDENT COUNSEL. Section 596(a)(1) of title 28, United States Code, is amended to allow for the removal of an independent counsel for failure to comply with Department of Justice policies. Section 596(b)(2) is amended to give the court the authority to terminate an independent counsel's office if the investigation is completed or substantially finished, upon certain conditions. The appointment of independent counsel can be terminated if the investigation is completed or not in the public interest. Monthly expenditures must be reported to specified committees. Periodic reappointment is allowed under certain conditions. The appointment of independent counsel can be terminated if the investigation is completed or not in the public interest. Periodic reappointment is allowed under certain conditions, requiring the counsel to apply for reappointment every 2 years. If the court determines the counsel is still appropriate for the role, they will be reappointed; otherwise, a qualified individual will be appointed. If the court fails to take action within 90 days, the office of independent counsel shall be terminated. The office of independent counsel shall terminate if the court fails to take action within 90 days after the end of the 2-year period. The Comptroller General of the United States will provide recommendations to Congress within 1 year on improving cost controls for independent counsel offices under chapter 40 of title 28, US Code.
